title: Singapore becomes first country in the world to ban adverts for drinks with high sugar content
text:
Singapore will become the first country in the world to ban adverts for drinks containing high levels of sugar in an effort to combat rising rates of diabetes.

The island-state's heath ministry announced Thursday that products deemed 'less healthy' will now have to carry labels grading their sugar content, with the worst offenders banned from advertising across TV, print and online.

'This aims to reduce the influence of such advertisements on consumer preferences,' the ministry said, calling the ban a world-first.

Singapore will force drink companies to put labels on their products ranking their sugar content, and the worst offenders will be banned from advertising (file image)

It added that the measures were only a start and it will continue to explore the possibility of a sugar tax or ban.

'We urge SSB (sugar-sweetened beverages) manufacturers to consider reformulating their drinks to contain less sugar even as we further study these measures,' it said.

The ministry said it will obtain industry feedback in the coming months on how to implement the measures and announce more details next year.

An International Diabetes Federation report in 2015 found that 13.7 per cent of Singaporean adults have diabetes, the second-highest rate in developed nations.

The island-state's health ministry announced the world-first ban Thursday, and said they are still considering further moves such as a sugar tax (file)

Diabetes is caused by having too much sugar in the blood, and there are two types - Type 1, which is genetic and cannot be treated, and Type 2, which is caused by poor diet and lack of exercise.

Some 420 million people around the world today suffer from diabetes, with the number expected to rise to 629 million by 2045, according to the International Diabetes Federation.

It is thought that around 90 per cent of the world's diabetics suffer from Type 2. In Singapore, this would translate to some 360,000 people.

Other marketing bans around the world have focused on restricting children's exposure to junk food ads.
description: Singapore will force drinks companies to put labels on their beverages ranking the sugar content and the worst offenders will be banned from advertising on TV, in print and online, the health ministry said.
